hedline.hl1: A Coffee Shop That Would Revive Rube Goldberg

block.p: Order coffee at the Roasting Plant, 81 Orchard Street (Broome Street), and instead of a barista pulling levers to fill your cup, a clerk will touch a computer screen.

Order coffee at the Roasting Plant, 81 Orchard Street (Broome Street), and instead of a barista pulling levers to fill your cup, a clerk will touch a computer screen.

The correct amount of whole coffee beans, roasted on the premises, right, will then whiz and clatter through a network of transparent plastic pipes overhead and drop into a compact countertop machine to be ground according to the type of coffee ordered. The beans are then brewed, in one seamless operation.
Regular coffee, as well as espresso, comes with an impressively creamy head, but it would not be mistaken for the cappuccino being prepared for Vanessa De Nola, right.
A choice of six single-origin beans can be blended to order, even in a single cup. A house blend, either regular or decaffeinated, is also available.
Coffee drinks are $1.75 to $4. Those sipped at the store, perhaps with a pastry from Tom Cat, are served in insulated glass cups, and those sold to go come in insulated paper cups.

Mike Caswell, the founder and a partner, is an industrial engineer who worked for Coffee Connection in Boston and then for Starbucks. He adapted the brewing machinery from a Swiss model, and the rest of the system was built for him in Florida.
The small roaster does its work in the window. Beans are available unroasted, or green, for $6.50 to $7 a pound; the prices double for roasted coffee, either whole beans or ground.
Mr. Caswell recommends waiting 24 hours before using freshly roasted beans, to get peak flavor: (212) 775-7755.
